arch:property.oc:show_val: L38 is poorly preserved mudbrick wall. We orginally saw it as a clear line of red fill then cut along side it to reveal a layer of melted mudbrick running thru the center of the trench abutting the surface but about 10cm above the surface L37. We later extended the locus to the west baulk to encompass the cobbles with red melted bricks beneath in L33. We cleared off what we could see of the red brick wall and changed locus to L41 as the fill directly below the wall. I thought that the cobble wall in L39 was related to this wall which is a little lower in elevation but the same color brick and the same kind of cobbles so we extended L41 to encompass the fill beneath both walls.
this is a poorly preserved mudbrick wall that has no discernable brick lines

arch:note.arch:string: Contexts excavated in trenches were recorded using the "locus system." A locus is any discrete three-dimensional entity excavated in a trench. The key to the locus system is the recognition that a locus is any one thing. Differences in soil composition or texture are therefore as important as, for example, the difference between a pit and a wall. If two entities were distinct, they were considered separate loci and were therefore assigned separate locus numbers. It should also be noted that every context excavated in a trench was given a locus number and thus the trench itself is made up completely of excavated loci.

arch:property.oc:show_val: no visible mudbrick lines, .10 - .20cm stone size
possible L39 mudbrick and cobble wall
poorly preserved mudbrick wall not able to see brick lines with two cobbles situated in red brick material
